awd_titl_txt: IIBR Instrumentation: Integrated optical imaging and machine-learning platforms for mapping 3D topology of nanoscale cellular structures
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the George Washington University to create a novel light microscopy platform to visualize and detect features of cell membranes in three dimensions (3D) at ultra-fine (nanometer-scale) localization accuracy and on living cells. The project also includes the development of a machine-learning algorithm as a low-cost alternative to predict real-time 3D changes from conventional 2D light microscopy data. This innovative research will enable cell biologists and biochemists to gain new training in disciplines including optics, lipid biophysics, and biomechanics. The research program will also educate students ranging from high school to graduate school with diverse backgrounds, including women and underrepresented minorities. Research outcomes will be disseminated via creation of a public database, peer-reviewed publications, and conference presentations. Outreach activities will include hosting high school summer interns and underrepresented minority students through the national SPARC program. Other societal benefits of this project are the potential extension of the use of the proposed instruments to additional biological research areas. 

This project will develop new tools to view and assess changes occurring in cell membranes, which may play key roles in important cellular processes. Current light microscopic technology cannot detect changes at a nanometer scale in 3D in living cells. However, the 3D nanometer-scale membrane morphologies and their changes are important features that control cell biology. To resolve these issues, this project will build an innovative light microscopy system that combines two existing technologies to enable ultra-fine, 3D detection of cell membrane morphology on living cells. The platform will be tested and validated on various cell types to ensure reliability and wide applicability. The new instrument will be complemented by a machine-learning based software tool that predicts 3D cellular features based on 2D data obtained by using conventional light microscopes. The software will both allow for broader use in research with conventional light microscopy, making it affordable for many settings, as well as further extend the capabilities of the newly developed hardware. These tools together have broad implications for advancing basic biology research, by facilitating a wide variety of studies addressing the effects of cell surface morphology on cell biological functions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Key Scientific Outcomes

1. Developing MAxSIM, an integrated 3d optical microscopy platform

We successfully built an innovative imaging system that combines two powerful microscopy techniques: two-dimensional structured illumination microscopy (2D-SIM) for super-resolution imaging and scanning-angle interference microscopy (SAIM) for accurate height measurements at the nanometer scale. By integrating these technologies, MAxSIM enables the study of live cell membranes with exceptional detail, allowing researchers to observe dynamic cellular processes that were previously difficult to capture.

2. Advancing 3D cellular imaging and membrane biophysics

Initially, we aimed to develop a machine-learning algorithm to predict 3D morphology from standard 2D images. However, during our research, we made an unexpected discovery: the dyes used for labeling cell membranes responded sensitively to mechanical properties of the membrane itself. This finding prompted us to pivot our focus towards studying membrane mechanics and its effects on cellular functions, which can be uniquely addressed using our MAxSIM platform.

Broader impacts on science and society

The outcomes of this project extend beyond fundamental scientific discoveries. The development of MAxSIM provides the research community with a powerful tool to study cellular dynamics in greater detail, which has broad implications for understanding diseases such as cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, and immune system dysfunctions. Additionally, this project has contributed to workforce development and STEM education:

1. Training and mentorship: We have provided hands-on research training to undergraduate and graduate students, as well as high school interns, many from underrepresented backgrounds in STEM. These trainees gained experience in advanced imaging techniques and computational analysis, preparing them for future careers in scientific research and biomedical engineering.

2. Public dissemination of research: Our findings have been shared through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and a publicly accessible research database. By making our results and methodologies available, we ensure that other scientists can build upon our work and apply MAxSIM technology to their own research.

3. Technology transfer: The algorithms and computational tools developed during this project have been shared via GitHub, enabling the broader scientific community to utilize and refine these resources. Furthermore, our findings on membrane mechanics have the potential to inform new biomedical applications.

Conclusion

This project has successfully addressed key challenges in 3D cellular imaging by developing MAxSIM, an innovative microscopy platform that enhances our ability to study cellular structures and membrane mechanics with high accuracy. In addition to advancing fundamental biological research, this work has contributed to education, training, and technology dissemination, ensuring a lasting impact on both science and society.

By improving our ability to visualize and understand the nanoscale organization of cell membranes, MAxSIM will continue to drive new discoveries in cell biology and biophysics, shaping future research in biomedical sciences.
